comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: What a beautifully produced map.  I love the drawings at top right.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: I agree. These old maps and plans really are beautiful and the detail in each one is extraordinary.

comment.author: 37426109@N07
comment._content: This map is amazing. I can even see my district along the river.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks for your comment,  Historically_Sympathetic. We're hoping to add more maps to our photostream soon.

comment.author: 77757580@N00
comment._content:
It's  amazing. I didn't realise Minto had settled so early. Also I love the area that says "Cow Pasture" now where modern day Hoxton Park, Hinchinbrook and Green Valley lie. 

Why does the map appear to be on its "side" though? Appearing to show the areas of south-west Sydney facing north. It makes for a weird perspective.  I think I can see a symbol showing north, but I'm so used to seeing maps with north facing upward these days, it took a few seconds to get the sense of perspective on the map initially.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Larelle_M_R, I'm not sure if there is a specific reason, other than the presentation of the map. Perhaps another Flickr friend might know?

comment.author: 36196524@N08
comment._content: I'm puzzled as to why the two hills have such prominence. The one at left may be Prospect Hill.  the one at right, in the Castle / Rogans Hill area, is labelled but I can't read it.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/36196524@N08] You're right: Prospect Hill is to the left; Castle Hill is to the right. They were both well-established farming areas by that time, having been part of early Colonial Australian settlement.
AB
